description: From Middle English frend, freend, from Old English frƒìond (‚Äúfriend‚Äù, literally ‚Äúloving[-one], lover‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *friund, from Proto-Germanic *frij≈çndz (‚Äúlover, friend‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *preyH- (‚Äúto like, love‚Äù), equivalent to free +‚Äé -nd.

Cognate with Saterland Frisian Fjund, Fr√º√ºnd (‚Äúfriend‚Äù), West Frisian freon, froen, freondinne (‚Äúfriend‚Äù), Dutch vriend (‚Äúfriend‚Äù), Low German Frund, Fr√ºnd (‚Äúfriend, relative‚Äù), Luxembourgish Fr√´nd (‚Äúfriend‚Äù), German Freund (‚Äúfriend‚Äù), Danish fr√¶nde (‚Äúkinsman‚Äù), Swedish fr√§nde (‚Äúkinsman, relative‚Äù), Icelandic fr√¶ndi (‚Äúkinsman‚Äù), Gothic êçÜêçÇêåπêåæêçâêåΩêå≥êçÉ (frij≈çnds, ‚Äúfriend‚Äù). entries.meaning: A person, typically someone other than a family member, spouse or lover, whose company one enjoys and towards whom one feels affection.
examples: The only reward of virtue is virtue; the only way to have a friend is to be one.
The Automobile Association is every motorist's friend.¬†¬† The police is every law-abiding citizen's friend.

entries.meaning: A person with whom one is vaguely or indirectly acquainted.
examples: a friend of a friend;¬† I added him as a friend on Facebook, but I hardly know¬†him.

entries.meaning: A person who backs or supports something.
examples: I‚Äôm not a friend of cheap wine.

entries.meaning: (informal) An object or idea that can be used for good.
(colloquial, ironic, used only in the vocative) Used as a form of address when warning someone.
(object-oriented programming) A function or class granted special access to the private and protected members of another class.

examples: Since they were introduced in the 1970s, friends have revolutionized climbing, making protection possible in previously impossible places  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (euphemistic) A lover; a boyfriend or girlfriend.
examples: Time has been, when a gentleman wanted a friend, I could supply him with choice in an hour; but the market is spoiled, and a body might as soon produce a hare or a partridge  [‚Ä¶]

entries.meaning: (Scotland, obsolete) A relative, a relation by blood or marriage.
examples: Friends agree best at a distance.

entries.meaning: (in the plural, usually preceded by "and") Used to refer collectively to a group of associated individuals, especially those comprising a cast, company, or crew
examples: Meanwhile on The View, Whoopi Goldberg and friends continue to issue forced apologies for their assumptive comments regarding non-profit organisation Turning Point USA...

verbs.description: friend (third-person singular simple present friends, present participle friending, simple past and past participle friended)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To act as a friend to, to befriend; to be friendly to, to help.
examples: Lo sluggish Knight the victors happie pray: / So fortune friends the bold [...].

entries.meaning: (transitive) To add (a person) to a list of friends on a social networking site; to officially designate (someone) as a friend.
examples: The difference between responses to the statement, "If someone friends me, I will friend them," and "If I friend someone, I expect them to friend me back," is telling.
